title-group.article-title: The Ophryotrocha diadema group (Annelida: Dorvilleidae), with the description of two new species

sec.p: The Ophryotrocha diadema group (Annelida: Dorvilleidae ), with the description of two new species
HANNELORE PAXTON1,2, 4 & BERTIL ÅKESSON 3
1 Department of Biological Sciences, Macquarie University, Sydney, NSW2109 , Australia2 Australian Museum, 6 College Street, Sydney, NSW2010 , Australia
3 Department of Zoology, Gothenburg University, Box 463 , SE- 40530 Gothenburg, Sweden4Corresponding author. E-mail: hannelore.paxton@mq.edu.au

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
This paper reviews a group of hermaphroditic Ophryotrocha species, here designated as the O . diadema
group. This informal group is characterised by its unique P-maxillae and paired mammillate rosette glands. The three members of the group are simultaneous hermaphrodites and have the chromosome complement of 2 n = 8 . As herein defined, the group includes O . diadema
, O . alborana
sp. nov. , and O . birgittae
sp. nov. . The three species can be distinguished by the appearance of their eyes and other morphological and reproductive differences. The species are described, and their life table data is presented.
Key words: Polychaetes, taxonomy, reproduction, development, nutrient-rich waters, life tables, population parameters

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Polychaetes of the genus Ophryotrocha Claparède & Mecznikow, 1869 , found in shallow, nutrient-rich waters such as harbours, have been collected and cultured by us for more than forty years. While the species are very similar in their external morphology, they differ greatly in their reproductive patterns, ranging from hermaphroditism to gonochorism and viviparity (
Åkesson 1975 a
). Crossing experiments of laboratory cultures led to the recognition of a number of new species, resulting in numerous publications, serving as models for developmental bioassays ( Åkesson 1970 , 1975b ) and reproductive and life cycle studies (Åkesson 1978, 1982;
Thornhill et al.2009 ). Phylogenetic analyses based on morphology, reproductive and electrophoretic characters (
Pleijel & Eide 1996 ) and DNA sequences (
Dahlgren et al.2001 ;
Heggøy et al.2007 ) identified some well supported clades. Studies of the O . labronica
group of species (referred to as clade B by
Dahlgren et al.2001 ) have recently been completed, presenting formal descriptions of seven species that were formerly known only by their laboratory names or nomina nuda (
Paxton & Åkesson 2010 ). We are here treating the O . diadema
group of species (referred to as clade A 2 by
Dahlgren et al.2001 ).

Members of the O . diadema
group are characterised by the combination of the following features: ( 1 ) palps absent, replaced by ciliary pads; ( 2 ) ciliary bands separated by gaps; ( 3 ) parapodial cirri absent; ( 4 ) mammillate rosette glands present, known previously only for Mammiphitime Orensanz, 1990 ; ( 5 ) pygidial dorsal stylus absent; ( 6 ) unique P-maxillae with forceps lacking the serrated comb-like plate and anterior denticles having additional oval ventral plates; ( 7 ) simultaneous hermaphroditism, chromosome complement of 2 n = 8 ; and relatively few, large eggs in fusiform egg cases. While the three species are morphologically very similar, they can be distinguished by their eyes and other morphological and reproductive differences. This paper will formally describe the two new species and compare life table data for the three members of the Ophryotrocha diadema group.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
The taxonomic study was largely based on the examination of live material reared in culture. Once a week the water ( 34 ‰ salinity) was changed and the worms were fed spinach which had been fragmented in a blender and soaked in sea water (
Åkesson 1970 ). The origins of the cultures are given in the individual species treatments. The animals examined at higher magnifications were anaesthetized in 6 % magnesium chloride and mounted on cavity slides, or squash preparations for jaw apparatuses. Specimens preserved for examination and/or type specimens were anaesthetized and fixed in 70 % ethanol. All drawings were made with the aid of a camera lucida. Photographs were taken with an Olympus SZH stereo microscope with Sony CFW- 310 C colour digital camera. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of O . diadema
and O . alborana
, sp. nov. were produced following
Rouse & Pleijel ( 2001 )
and were fixed in 1 % osmium tetroxide in seawater, critical-point dried, gold coated and examined with a JEOL JSM- 6480 LA. Specimens of O . birgittae
, sp. nov. were treated with hexamethyldisilazane ( HMDS ) instead of critical point drying. Type specimens have been deposited at the Australian Museum, Sydney (AM) and the Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm ( SMNH ).

The life-table study followed 120 fertilised eggs of each of the three species. Embryos and early larvae were observed within the egg masses. Released larvae were distributed among 30 ml bowls, 10 in each bowl. The experiment was not terminated until the last animal had died.

Material examined. Live cultures from specimens collected in a small-boat marina, Long Beach, California, U.S.A. , by Bertil Åkesson, 1989 . Additional preserved material from same culture: 50 specimens
( SMNH117237 ), 0.5–2.1 mm long ( 5–18 chaetigers); 50 specimens
(AM W. 37221 ), 0.5–2.3 mm long ( 4–18 chaetigers).

Description. Length of most live adults 2.5–3.5 mm ( 15–17 chaetigers), maximum length 4.6 mm ( 25 chaetigers) (
Table 1 ). Live animals (
A) translucent, preserved opaque white. Prostomium anteriorly rounded, wider than long, dorsoventrally flattened, bearing pair of dorsal cylindrical antennae, palps absent, replaced by ciliated pads (
A, B). Anterior part of prostomium and tips of antennae with small bundles of adjoined tactile cilia, appearing spike-like in living animals. Ciliary bands separated by gaps; two bands of cilia encircling prostomium, one complete circle in front of antennae, and one incomplete circle at level of antennae. Latter interrupted by antennae; cilia between antennae slanting posteriorly, separated by small mid-dorsal space, giving appearance of eyebrows. Additional ventral semicircle of cilia anterior to complete circle. Posterior border of prostomium indicated dorsally by four nuchal organs, ventrally by mouth, lateral restrictions almost absent.

Peristomium represented by two apodous, achaetous segment-like rings, each surrounded by complete circle of cilia. Two eyes, slightly below border between prostomium and peristomium, between inner and outer nuchal organs. Eyes internal, visible only in living animals. Eyes with refractive crystalline platelets as typical for Ophryotrocha , appearing silvery white under incident light. Crystalline platelets irregularly branching, extending medially and anteriorly, forming triangular luminous area together with eyes (
A). Following chaetigers with dorsal and ventral ciliary bands, laterally interrupted by parapodia.

Reproduction and development.Ophryotrocha diadema is hermaphroditic. The first and second chaetigers are sterile, the third and fourth are male, and the remainder are female. The chromosome number is 2 n = 8 . Newly laid eggs are ovoid, 200 x 180 µm. The egg case is firm and elastic, transparent, and of fusiform shape, closed at both ends. The larvae are released from the egg case at the 4 -chaetiger stage.The jaw ontogeny has been described and illustrated on the basis of SEM images by
Macnaughton et al. ( 2010 )
. Larval maxillae are present in up to 5 - chaetiger animals, juvenile (P 1 ) maxillae are found only in 6 - and 7 -chaetiger animals, and adult (P 2 ) maxillae from 7 - to 8 -chaetiger animals onwards. Other reproductive and population parameters are listed in
Table 2 and will be compared for the three species in the “Discussion” below.

Remarks.Ophryotrocha diadema was originally collected in
August 1972 by Dr. Donald J. Reish (and his daughter) in the harbour of Los Angeles. It proved to be a rare species among those sampled. Only two individuals were brought to Gothenburg together with several hundreds of O . labronica pacifica
.
In 1989 , a second collection of more than 50 specimens
was made by Åkesson in a small-boat marina in Long Beach, California. The best site was an old piece of rope, overgrown by mussels and other fouling organisms, with O . diadema
living in the interstices of that fouling community. Recently it has been found in the Sicilian harbour of Porto Empedocle (
Simonini et al. 2009
, 2010 ), presumably resulting from anthropogenic activities, e.g., transport of ballast water or in fouling material of ships.

Both the two individuals of 1972 and the population of 1989 carried an egg colour polymorphism, a diallelic mutation with one dominant ( Y ) and one recessive allele (w) expressing itself as white or pale yellow. The white eggs of the (ww) homozygotes result from the inability of the worms to synthesize lutein (
Sella & Marzoná 1982 ). The mutation remains in the population due to a higher fecundity of the heterozygotes (
Åkesson 1976 ). The YY, Yw, and ww genotypes of O . diadema
have been compared in a life table analysis (
Åkesson 1982 ). In the present comparison performed here we used the wild type data (
Table 2 ).

Abiotic factors, such as temperature and salinity and their effect on reproduction, have been studied by
Åkesson & Costlow ( 1978 )
. The optimum salinity is 33 ‰, the optimum temperature occurs at 25 ºC. In order to facilitate comparisons with the two new species, we have run life tables in a combination of 33 ‰ salinity and 21 ºC.

Ophryotrocha diadema is one of the best known polychaetes to be used for bioassays. Many details of its life history can be recorded in those assays: ( 1 ) time from spawning to larval release; ( 2 ) the fate of the embryos inside the transparent egg mass; ( 3 ) the time from larval release to spawning of virginal individuals. It is important, however, to know the genetic properties of the strain used for assays (
Åkesson 1982 ).
Reish & Carr ( 1978 )
used O . diadema
in an analysis of heavy metals.
Hooftman & Vink ( 1980 )
reported on toxic effects of dieldrin and two other chemicals. They compared short-term and long-term effects.
Klöckner ( 1979 )
studied effects of cadmium on three consecutive generations. Recently,
Knowles & Greenwood ( 1994 )
used seven continuous generations of O . diadema
to study effects of doses of gamma radiation.
Distribution. Pacific Ocean: Los Angeles and Long Beach, California; Mediterranean Sea: Porto Empedocle, Sicily.

Table 2 and will be compared for the three species in the “Discussion” below.

Dahlgren et al.2001 ;
Heggøy et al.2007 ). It can be distinguished from the other two species of the O . diadema
group by having eyes with a reddish pigment cup in addition to the silvery white crystalline platelets (
), as well as other subtle morphological differences (
Table 1 ), and differing life history parameters (
Table 2 ).

Ophryotrocha alborana was collected in
February 1978 in the harbour of Algeciras, in the Alboran Sea, the westernmost portion of the Mediterranean Sea. It coexisted with O . hartmanni
Huth, 1933 , O . puerilis
Claparède & Mecznikow, 1869 , and O . labronica
La Greca & Bacci, 1962 . A few days later it was also found in Ceuta , the Spanish enclave on the Moroccan coast, together with O . puerilis
, O . rubra
Paxton & Åkesson, 2010 and O . robusta
Paxton & Åkesson, 2010 . Despite repeated searches, O . alborana
has never been found again in either locality.

G). Shafts of adult animals 125–140 µm long, with basal and distal lateral thickenings (
H). Maxillary apparatus of P-type only, consisting of forceps fused with carrier-like structure and seven pairs of anterior denticles (D) (
C). Forceps of adult worms 90–125 µm long, median edge of anterior part of forceps with large distal fang and 3–5 large teeth irregularly alternating with small teeth, distal fang much larger than other large teeth (
I); D 1 –D 3 with distal fang and coarsely serrated median cutting edge; D 4 –D 7 with finely serrated edge, associated with oval ventral plate.

A) are present in up to 6 -chaetiger animals, juvenile (P 1 ) maxillae (
B) are found in 7 - to 11 -chaetiger animals, and adult (P 2 ) maxillae (
C) from 12 -chaetiger animals onwards. Other reproductive and population parameters are listed in
Table 2 and will be compared for the three species in the ‘Discussion” below.
Etymology. This species is named in honour of Birgitta Åkesson, in appreciation of her continuous support and understanding.

Remarks. The new species was originally identified through crossbreeding experiments and has been confirmed by gene sequence studies (
Dahlgren et al.2001 ;
Heggøy et al . 2007 ). It can be distinguished from the other two species of the O . diadema
group by having separate reflective eyes, while in O . diadema
the eyes are connected, and those of O . alborana
have an additional red pigment cup (
), as well as other subtle morphological differences (
Table 1 ), and differing life history parameters (
Table 2 ).

An egg colour polymorphism resulting from a recessive mutant causing the eggs to be white instead of yellow, described for O . diadema
above, has also been observed in O . birgittae
.

Ophryotrocha puerilis was reported from the littoral zone of Qingdao harbour by
Wu ( 1981 )
. Wu stated that it occurred in abundance and remained on muddy stones during low tides, suggesting that it might be identical with the species described here. However, the sketch accompanying Wu’s note shows the presence of palps which are found in O . puerilis
but absent in O . birgittae
.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Morphology and reproduction.As far as size and overall morphology are concerned, the three species of the O . diadema
group are typical members of Ophryotrocha . Their coherence as a group has been demonstrated by phylogenetic analyses employing electrophoresis (
Pleijel & Eide 1996 ) and DNA sequences (Dahlgren el al.2001 ;
Heggøy et al.2007 ). The clade can further be characterised by the combination of a number of morphological and reproductive attributes which are discussed below. Most of these are also found in other members of the genus; however, it is the combination of these features that characterise the three species as a coherent group.

( 1 ) Prostomial palps are absent, but in the ventrolateral position where palps would be located, we find adjoined tactile cilia that appear in SEM images as ciliary pads (
E). Similarly reduced palps have been reported for O . socialis
Ockelmann & Åkesson, 1990 .

( 2 ) The cilia making up ciliary bands are not just continuous rows. High resolution SEM images show them as bundles of cilia with each bundle acting as a unit (e.g.
Paxton & Åkesson 2007 :
B). In previously studied species this has been overlooked since the bundles are so close to each other that they appear as a continuous row. In the O . diadema
group however, the individual bundles are visible in all three species as they are separated by small gaps (
G).

( 4 ) Mammillate rosette glands. Rosette glands, large segmental epidermal glands were first described by
Braem ( 1893 )
for O . puerilis
and named for the circular arrangement of their oblong cells. They are paired flat dorsal structures in the posterior segments of O . puerilis
and O . shieldsi
Paxton & Davey, 2010 , paired flat ventral in O . hartmanni
, and single flat dorsal in the O . labronica
group ( Paxton & Åkesson 2007 , 2010 ). While they have been recognised only for a small group of species, they are most likely present in all species of Ophryotrocha .
The function of the rosette glands is unknown, although a role in mating or spawning is presumed. Schlawny (l 983 ) investigated the morphology and histochemistry of the rosette glands, established that they secrete basic proteins in granular form and speculated that the secretions act as pheromones.

Members of the O . diadema
group have rosette glands that range from being slightly raised to little mounds, topped by a nipple-like extension, ending in a flat, perforated area (
C, D, G; 4 E, F; 5 F). Similar structures were first described for Ophryotrocha cosmetandra Oug, 1990 as dorsolateral processes on posterior segments of males (
Oug 1990 ).
Orensanz ( 1990 )
observed these ‘mammillate’ structures in a new Antarctic species, and erected the genus Mammiphitime Orensanz, 1990 for M. tridentata Orensanz, 1990 . Besides the mammillate glands, the genus was diagnosed as having composite spinigers, tridentate mandibles, and P- and K-maxillae, characters that are also found in M. cosmetandra .

The mammillate structures of Mammiphitime have a similar appearance to the rosette glands of the O . diadema
group. Based on their location and histological studies by
Oug ( 1990 )
we recognise them also as rosette glands. Their occurrence in two genera raises the issues that the rosette glands either evolved their mammillate shape independenly, or it puts the validity of Mammiphitime in doubt, as it would place Mammiphitime within Ophryotrocha .

( 5 ) A pygidial dorsal stylus is present in many juvenile Ophryotrocha species but absent in adults (e.g. O . labronica
group), or even remains as a small structure in O . puerilis
and O . socialis
.
In the O . diadema
group, however, it has not been observed in any stage.

FIGURE 6. Maxillary apparatuses of Ophryotrocha birgittae
, sp. nov. . A, Larval maxillae (L) of 4-chaetiger worm, dorsal view; B, Juvenile maxillae (P1) of 11-chaetiger worm, dorsal view; C, Adult maxillae (P2) of 13-chaetiger worm, dorsolateral view. Abbreviations: F, forceps; numerals refer to anterior denticles.

( 6 ) As typical for Ophryotrocha , the maxillary apparatus goes through a series of moults from the initial larval jaws to the juvenile (P 1 ) and adult (P 2 ) maxillae. Each jaw stage consists of basal plates or forceps fused with a carrier-like structure and anterior denticles (D). All maxillary elements are interconnected by the cuticle. The larval maxillae (L) (
A) consist of only four paired plates and are similar to other Ophryotrocha larval maxillae. The pair of dorsalmost posterior slender plates represent the larval forceps, followed by a pair of large plates representing D 1 and two pairs of smaller plates of the D 4–7type . The juvenile maxillae (
B) are of the same type as the adult ones but have only six pairs of anterior denticles, while the adult maxillae have seven pairs (
I, J; 6 C). The P-maxillae of the O . diadema
group have some unique features. While the forceps look similar to those of O . puerilis
, O . gracilis
and O . hartmanni
(clade A 1 of
Dahlgren et al.2001 ), closer inspection shows an important difference. The only serrations on the forceps of the O . diadema
group are on the median edge. However, in O . puerilis
and related species, the forceps have a little finely serrated comb-like structure slightly posterior and lateral to the main serrated edge (
Paxton & Åkesson 2007 :
E
). Another important characteristic of the P-maxillae of the O . diadema
group is that the anterior denticles D 4 to D 7 are ventrally associated with small sclerotised plates. In a squash preparation the little plates become laterally displaced and can be visible as sclerotised oval structures on the clear cuticle (
C). Their in situ position is better realised in a ventral view SEM image of the maxillae, where the plates are clearly associated with the anterior denticles D 4 to D 7 (
I). The most anterior one, associated with (D 7 ), is slightly smaller and not visible in the squash preparations. Similar structures have only been reported in one other species of Ophryotrocha ,
namely O . lipscombae
Lu & Fauchald, 2000 from the U.S. Atlantic slope, from a depth of 1830 m . The K-type maxillae of this species were reported to have two rows of five sclerotised black accessory plates, associated with D 1 and D 5 to D 7 .
FIGURE 7. Fecundity in Ophryotrocha alborana , sp. nov. .

( 7 ) The three species of the O . diadema
group are simultaneous hermaphrodites, have a chromosome complement of 2 n = 8 , and relatively few, large eggs in fusiform egg cases. Although one or two of these reproductive characteristics are also found in other species, the combination of all three is limited to the O . diadema
group.

Life table studies. Water temperature. Temperature and salinity are important influences on the life cycle of small shallow water marine organisms like Ophryotrocha species.
Åkesson & Costlow ( 1978 )
have studied these effects on O . diadema
and have shown that reproduction and larval development was successful between 11 ºC and 27 ºC. The strain studied originated from Los Angeles, where the mean water temperatures vary between 14.4 ºC and 20 ºC during the year. Here we are presenting results of fecundity studies in O . alborana
, from the Alboran Sea (
). At 18 ºC, fecundity is about 90 % of the figures for 21 ºC, whereas 15 ºC yields only 40 % of the optimum fecundity at 21 ºC. At 25 ºC, fecundity is even lower, only about 15 % of optimum fecundity. The results show that the range of optimum temperatures is narrow; this agrees with surface water temperatures for the Alboran Sea ranging from 16 ºC in February to 22.5 ºC in October. Future studies, extending such investigations to O . birgittae
should be interesting, as the mean water temperatures in Qingdao harbour range from 3 ºC in February to 25 ºC in August, requiring a huge tolerance.

FIGURE 10. Age-specific reproductive values.
FIGURE 11. Age-specific variation in time intervals between consecutive spawnings.

Population parameters. The average length of life is superior in O . birgittae
with 85 weeks, followed by O . diadema
with 50 , and O . alborana
with 28 weeks (
). It is interesting to note the respective points to 50 % survival, which are 60, 27, and 18 weeks (
), in other words, at 71 %, 54 % and 64 % of their respective life times. Although O . alborana
has the lowest life expectancy of the three species, in the lack of competition we have been able to maintain thriving populations of O . alborana
at the laboratory for more than 30 years.

The population parameters of the three species are summarised in
Table 2 . Surprisingly, the intrinsic rate of increase ( r ) was highest for O . diadema
, even though their population doubling time was lowest. The intrinsic rate of increase, r /wk, is part of the Lotka equation: Σ e–rx l x m x= 1 . It is the fraction at which a population is growing at each instant of time. Three major factors are included: ( 1 ) natality, ( 2 ) mortality, and ( 3 ) time from zygote formation to the first spawning (
Lewontin 1965 ). The high figures for life expectancy and the larger number of eggs per egg mass does not bring O . birgittae
up to the same level as O . diadema
.
This can be explained by the fact that the reproductive value (Vx) of O . diadema
during the first ten weeks of life is much higher than that of O . birgittae
(
). The age specific variation in time intervals between consecutive spawnings for the three species demonstrates that while O . diadema
does not live as long as O . birgittae
,
the former spawns more often than the latter as shown in
.

When comparing morphological characteristics (
Table 1 ) and the data from the life tables (
Table 2 ), it appears that O . birgittae
has more in common with O . diadema
than with O . alborana
,
even though DNA sequencing analyses are ambiguous in this respect.
Dahlgren et al. ( 2001 )
aligned O . alborana
and O . diadema
as sister species with O . birgittae
more basally, while the analyses of
Heggøy et al. ( 2007 )
remained equivocal.
